meanings.definition: Very vivid in color, especially so as to create an unpleasantly harsh or unnatural effect.
meanings.sent1: The lurid sunset painted the sky in bright, unsettling colors.
meanings.sent2: The artist used lurid shades of red and green to create a dramatic painting.
meanings.sent3: The lurid flowers in the garden seemed to glow eerily in the moonlight.
meanings.sent4: Her lurid hair stood out like a neon sign in the dimly lit room.
meanings.sent5: The lurid neon lights of the city at night were both captivating and unsettling.

meanings.definition: Presented in vividly shocking or sensational terms, especially giving explicit details of crimes or sexual matters.
meanings.sent1: The newspaper published a lurid story about a scandalous affair.
meanings.sent2: The movie depicted the crime scene in lurid detail, shocking the audience.
meanings.sent3: The lurid gossip at the party was so exaggerated it sounded like a soap opera plot.
meanings.sent4: Her lurid descriptions of the crime scene made everyone gasp in horror.
meanings.sent5: The lurid headlines on the tabloid newspaper were hard to ignore.

meanings.sent1: The horror movie was filled with lurid scenes of blood and gore.
meanings.sent2: The abandoned house had a lurid history of mysterious disappearances.
meanings.sent3: The lurid smell coming from the kitchen made everyone lose their appetite.
meanings.sent4: His lurid nightmares kept him awake at night, trembling in fear.
meanings.sent5: The lurid details of the crime were too disturbing to discuss.
